Quoting hyysguyang <hyysguyang@...>:
> The final step is to refactor =
to remove duplicate code.
>
> a) Remove the duplicate string in the test ca=
se and product code.
>
>    public class StringReverser {
>        public S=
tring reverse(String str) {
>            String[] words=3Dstr.split(" ");
>=
            StringBuilder result=3Dnew StringBuilder();
>            for (i=
nt i =3D words.length-1; i >=3D0; i--) {
>                result.append(wor=
ds[i]).append(" ");
>            }
>            return result.toString().tr=
im();
>        }
>    }

It seems like there is a large jump in the amount =
of code in this  
refactoring step. If it were just removing the duplicate =
space, you  
could do that with something like a hardcoded array:

String[]=
 reversedSentence =3D { "technology", "devolopment", "software",  
"a", "is=
", "Tdd" };
for (String word: reversedSentence) {
	result.append(word, " ")=
;
}

That is certainly one possible route.

You might try to instead think =
in terms of moving from the simplest  
possible case and adding complexity =
incrementally to the test cases.  
The simplest possible test case here? Em=
pty string, do nothing. Write  
the code to get this to pass. This gets you=
r interface in place.

Then consider the next most simple case: one word. R=
eversal is the  
same as the input. You have to check for the existence of =
the  
separator character (indexOf is probably sufficient).

Then move to t=
he next case, which would probably be two words. You  
don't need a loop to=
 implement this case.

Then write a case for multiple words. A loop is prob=
ably prudent at  
this point.

Finally, oddball/edge cases: Does your algor=
ithm work for multiple  
spaces inbetween words? Should it retain the same =
input spacing (or  
not?). Write a test.

You'll end up with a more compreh=
ensive set of test cases, and more  
importantly, you'll have arrived at th=
e solution more incrementally.

Jeff
